Field Label:
Hello [Patient's Name],
My name is [Your Name], and I am the [Study Coordinator] at the University of Florida. I am contacting you to see if you are interested in participating in a research study focused on understanding pain and recovery after knee and hip replacement surgery. During a past clinic visit,  you signed a consent form telling us you were interested in being  contacted for future research that you may qualify for.

Are you interested in hearing more about this research study?

Do you have about 10-15 minutes now to talk about the study or should we schedule a more convenient time? [If now is fine, continue. If not, schedule a time to call them back.]
The purpose of this study is to identify factors that predict pain and function after undergoing knee or hip replacement. If you choose to participate, you will be one of 300 people to take part in this study. Your participation will require 5 visits over a period of nine months, with two of these visits occurring virtually (you will not be required to come in to our clinic). These sessions will last approximately 20 minutes to 2.5 hours. 
If eligible, a baseline research appointment will be scheduled. This appointment will take place within 2-4 weeks of your surgery. After the initial appointment, you will be asked to attend four visits over the course of 9 months after your surgery. 
During these visits, you will be asked to complete a series of questionnaires, a brief physical activity test, an exam assessing your perception of pressure and heat sensation, and heart rate monitoring.  You will also be asked to collect saliva at three of your visits and to wear a Garmin watch for collection of sleep and physical activity. In recognition of your time, you will be paid a maximum of $400 for completing the study.

Field Label: Repeated Chair Stands Do you think it would be safe for you to try to stand up from a chair five times without using your arms? (Demonstrate and explain the procedure) : Please stand up straight as QUICKLY as you can five times, without stopping in between. After standing up each time, sit down and then stand up again. Keep your arms folded across your chest. I'll be timing you with a stopwatch. When the participant is properly seated, say: "Ready? Stand" and begin timing. Count out loud as the participant arises each time, up to five times. Stop if participant becomes tired or short of breath during repeated chair stands. Stop the stopwatch when he/she has straightened up completely for the fifth time. Also stop: - If participant uses his/her arms - After 1 minute, if participant has not completed rises - At your discretion, if concerned for participant's safety If the participant stops and appears to be fatigued before completing the five stands, confirm this by asking "Can you continue?" If participant says "Yes," continue timing. If participant says "No," stop and reset the stopwatch.

If five stands done successfully, record time in seconds.

General Information: The patient should sit on a standard armchair, placing his/her back against the chair and resting his/her arms comfortably on his/her lap or at his/her sides. Any assistive device used for walking should be nearby. Regular footwear and customary walking aids should be used. The patient should walk to a line that is 3 meters (9.8 feet) away, turn around at the line, walk back to the chair, and sit down. The test ends when the patient's buttocks touch the seat. A stopwatch should be used to time the test (in seconds).
